text:
Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

---

In my opinion, being outraged about what goes through the heads of others is an unproductive way to do activism. At the end of the day, it's not about what people think, it's about what they do.

---

In my opinion, being outraged about what goes through the heads of others is an unproductive way to do activism. At the end of the day, it's not about what people think, it's about what they do. While 40 percent of people may have said they would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist, it's another matter entirely what they would do in real life if faced in that situation.

In my opinion, being outraged about what goes through the heads of others is an unproductive way to do activism. At the end of the day, it's not about what people think, it's about what they do. While 40 percent of people may have said they would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist, it's another matter entirely what they would do in real life if faced in that situation. 

The fact is, most people don't want to think about the suffering of others at all, whether they're human or animal or even a plant. Humans are emotional and sympathetic creatures, with a vibrant capacity to feel pain; thus, we will often do anything to avoid those feelings of pain.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, being outraged about what goes through the heads of others is an unproductive way to do activism. At the end of the day, it's not about what people think, it's about what they do. While 40 percent of people may have said they would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist, it's another matter entirely what they would do in real life if faced in that situation. 

The fact is, most people don't want to think about the suffering of others at all, whether they're human or animal or even a plant. Humans are emotional and sympathetic creatures, with a vibrant capacity to feel pain; thus, we will often do anything to avoid those feelings of pain. It's important to recognize that it can often be easier for a human to ruminate on the suffering of an animal as opposed to the suffering of a fellow human, because the animal is more distant to us and therefore harder to empathize with completely. This doesn't necessarily speak to any given human's true morality, but rather their emotional coping mechanisms when faced with difficult moral questions.

The question of whether it's wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering is a fallacious one. In fact, activists can care about multiple causes at once.

The question of whether it's wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering is a fallacious one. In fact, activists can care about multiple causes at once. It's not a zero-sum game.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, being outraged about what goes through the heads of others is an unproductive way to do activism. At the end of the day, it's not about what people think, it's about what they do. While 40 percent of people may have said they would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist, it's another matter entirely what they would do in real life if faced in that situation. 

The fact is, most people don't want to think about the suffering of others at all, whether they're human or animal or even a plant. Humans are emotional and sympathetic creatures, with a vibrant capacity to feel pain; thus, we will often do anything to avoid those feelings of pain. It's important to recognize that it can often be easier for a human to ruminate on the suffering of an animal as opposed to the suffering of a fellow human, because the animal is more distant to us and therefore harder to empathize with completely. This doesn't necessarily speak to any given human's true morality, but rather their emotional coping mechanisms when faced with difficult moral questions.

The question of whether it's wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering is a fallacious one. In fact, activists can care about multiple causes at once; it's not a zero-sum game. Much in the same way that somebody can care about ending homelessness and ending racism, somebody else can care about protecting animals and protecting humans. There's never anything wrong with caring, because caring about something does not preclude the possibility of caring about other things, whether they're "worthy" causes or not. Suggesting that one group (or species, as it were) is more important and worthy than another is simply a way to divide people who could otherwise be driven to unite over the same cause. Instead of a world where people have to choose between animals and humans, why not a world where everybody cares about both?

Animals and humans are both worthy of

In my opinion, being outraged about what goes through the heads of others is an unproductive way to do activism. At the end of the day, it's not about what people think, it's about what they do. While 40 percent of people may have said they would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist, it's another matter entirely what they would do in real life if faced in that situation. 

The fact is, most people don't want to think about the suffering of others at all, whether they're human or animal or even a plant. Humans are emotional and sympathetic creatures, with a vibrant capacity to feel pain; thus, we will often do anything to avoid those feelings of pain. It's important to recognize that it can often be easier for a human to ruminate on the suffering of an animal as opposed to the suffering of a fellow human, because the animal is more distant to us and therefore harder to empathize with completely. This doesn't necessarily speak to any given human's true morality, but rather their emotional coping mechanisms when faced with difficult moral questions.

The question of whether it's wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering is a fallacious one. In fact, activists can care about multiple causes at once; it's not a zero-sum game. Much in the same way that somebody can care about ending homelessness and ending racism, somebody else can care about protecting animals and protecting humans. There's never anything wrong with caring, because caring about something does not preclude the possibility of caring about other things, whether they're "worthy" causes or not. Suggesting that one group (or species, as it were) is more important and worthy than another is simply a way to divide people who could otherwise be driven to unite over the same cause. Instead of a world where people have to choose between animals and humans, why not a world where everybody cares about both?

Animals and humans are both worthy of our empathy, and it's important to recognize that.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, being outraged about what goes through the heads of others is an unproductive way to do activism. At the end of the day, it's not about what people think, it's about what they do. While 40 percent of people may have said they would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist, it's another matter entirely what they would do in real life if faced in that situation. 

The fact is, most people don't want to think about the suffering of others at all, whether they're human or animal or even a plant. Humans are emotional and sympathetic creatures, with a vibrant capacity to feel pain; thus, we will often do anything to avoid those feelings of pain. It's important to recognize that it can often be easier for a human to ruminate on the suffering of an animal as opposed to the suffering of a fellow human, because the animal is more distant to us and therefore harder to empathize with completely. This doesn't necessarily speak to any given human's true morality, but rather their emotional coping mechanisms when faced with difficult moral questions.

The question of whether it's wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering is a fallacious one. In fact, activists can care about multiple causes at once; it's not a zero-sum game. Much in the same way that somebody can care about ending homelessness and ending racism, somebody else can care about protecting animals and protecting humans. There's never anything wrong with caring, because caring about something does not preclude the possibility of caring about other things, whether they're "worthy" causes or not. Suggesting that one group (or species, as it were) is more important and worthy than another is simply a way to divide people who could otherwise be driven to unite over the same cause. Instead of a world where people have to choose between animals and humans, why not a world where everybody cares about both?

Animals and humans are both worthy of our empathy, and it's important to recognize that. Life itself is precious, and we should all be working together to protect it.

Is It Wrong to Focus on Animal Welfare When Humans Are Suffering?

Would you be surprised to hear that a study found that research subjects were more upset by stories of a dog beaten by a baseball bat than of an adult similarly beaten? Or that other researchers found that if forced to choose, 40 percent of people would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist.

Why do you think many people are more empathetic toward the suffering of animals than that of people? In your opinion, is it wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering? Why do you think so?

---

In my opinion, being outraged about what goes through the heads of others is an unproductive way to do activism. At the end of the day, it's not about what people think, it's about what they do. While 40 percent of people may have said they would save their pet dog over a foreign tourist, it's another matter entirely what they would do in real life if faced in that situation. 

The fact is, most people don't want to think about the suffering of others at all, whether they're human or animal or even a plant. Humans are emotional and sympathetic creatures, with a vibrant capacity to feel pain; thus, we will often do anything to avoid those feelings of pain. It's important to recognize that it can often be easier for a human to ruminate on the suffering of an animal as opposed to the suffering of a fellow human, because the animal is more distant to us and therefore harder to empathize with completely. This doesn't necessarily speak to any given human's true morality, but rather their emotional coping mechanisms when faced with difficult moral questions.

The question of whether it's wrong to focus on animal welfare when humans are suffering is a fallacious one. In fact, activists can care about multiple causes at once; it's not a zero-sum game. Much in the same way that somebody can care about ending homelessness and ending racism, somebody else can care about protecting animals and protecting humans. There's never anything wrong with caring, because caring about something does not preclude the possibility of caring about other things, whether they're "worthy" causes or not. Suggesting that one group (or species, as it were) is more important and worthy than another is simply a way to divide people who could otherwise be driven to unite over the same cause. Instead of a world where people have to choose between animals and humans, why not a world where everybody cares about both?

Animals and humans are both worthy of our empathy, and it's important to recognize that. Life itself is precious, and we should all be working together to protect it. While "working together" may not necessarily mean volunteering hands-on at a farm or attending the same pro-rights protest, it does mean respecting the decisions that each individual makes about where to devote their time, energy and compassion. Our job as activists isn't to spy over the shoulder of our neighbors, waiting for them to slip up or have the wrong priorities, but to support each other in the causes that we all care about. There's nothing wrong with caring about both animals and people too, because at the end of the day, the most important thing is that we care at all.
